head.title: National Briefing | West: California: Judge Backs Schools In Race Case

hedline.hl1: National Briefing | West: California: Judge Backs Schools In Race Case

abstract.p: Judge Winifred Y Smith of California rules that Berkeley Unified School District did not violate state law when considering race in assigning students to programs; says district appropriately uses racial demographics, rather than race of individual students, in deciding student placement (S)

block.p: A judge has ruled that the Berkeley Unified School District does not violate state law when considering race in assigning students to programs. The ruling stems from a lawsuit filed last year by the Pacific Legal Foundation, a supporter of a 1996 ballot measure designed to abolish the use of sexual and racial preferences in government hiring and contracts. The judge, Winifred Y. Smith of Alameda County Superior Court, ruled Friday that the district appropriately used racial demographics, rather than the race of individual students, in deciding student placement. But the judge let stand the lawsuit's challenge to a mentoring and tutoring program.
